titleStmt.title: The Bloody husband, and cruell neighbour. Or, A true historie of two murthers, lately committed in Laurence Parish, in the Isle of Thanet in Knet, neer Sandwich: one murther by the hands of Adam Sprackling Esquire, who upon the 12th day of December last, being Sabbath day; in the morning, cut, mangled, and murthered his own wife; for which fact he was hanged at Sandwich upon Wednesday the 27th day of April last, 1653. The other the murther of Richard Langly, of the same parish, whose blood also (as is here shewed) cryed against the said Mr. Sprackling, written by one that lives neer the place where the said murthers were committed, and was present at Mr. Sprackling's tryall; and published for the warning, and good of all. May 13. 1653. Imprimatur, Edm. Calamy.

Or, A True Hi≈øtorie Of TWO MVRTHERS, Lately committed in Laurence Pari≈øh, in the I≈øle of Thanet in Kent, neer Sandwich:

One Murther By the hands of Adam Sprackling E≈øquire, who upon the 12th day of December la≈øt, being Sabbath day; in the morning, cut, mangled, and murthered his own wife; for which fact he was hanged at Sandwich upon Wedne≈øday the 27th day of April la≈øt, 1653.
The other The Murther of Richard Langly, of the ≈øame Pari≈øh, who≈øe blood al≈øo (as is here ≈øhewed) cryed again≈øt the ≈øaid Mr. Sprackling,

q.p: Blood defileth the Land, and the Land cannot be clen≈øed of the blood that is ≈øhed therein, but by the blood of him that ≈øhed it.

div.head: THE BLOODY HUSBAND, AND Cruell Neighbour, &c.
div.p: GOD that made man after his own Image, made a Law, Gen. 9.6. Who ≈øo ≈øheddeth mans blood, by man ≈øhall his blood be ≈øhed; for, in the Image of God made he man. Again≈øt this ≈øin of Murther, the wrath of God hath been revealed from heaven, by his ju≈øt and daily revengings of innocent blood upon Murtherers. Trea≈øurers of Examples of Judgements in this kind, both old and new, ly before us; From the time of bloudy Cain, to the blood thir≈øty Popi≈øh Rebels in Ireland, to which ≈ølaughter men of the Scarlet whore of Rome, God hath given plenty of blood to drink. We ≈øee bloody men daily cut off by the Sword of Ju≈øtice in all places. The late Execution of the Wife-murtherer at I≈ølington, neer London, And the late Murthers in the I≈øle of Thanet in the County of Kent, and the judgement of God on the Murtherers, call for a book, wherein they may be written for examples to the Generations pre≈øent and to come.

Adam Sprackling E≈øquire, of St. Laurence Pari≈øh in that I≈øle, about 20. year ≈øince, married Katherine, the
Daughter of Sir Robert Leukner, of Kent; This Gentleman having a fair e≈øtate in Lands, and being above thou≈øands of his Nelghbours in E≈øtate, wanting the grace of Humility, exalted him≈øelf above mea≈øure, affected preheminence in all Companies, u≈øed, in his braveries, long hair, &c. to ride about the I≈øland, and frequent Taphou≈øes, and there to Rant and roar, game and ≈øwear exceedingly, upon the lea≈øt provocation, and u≈øed to quarrell and draw his weapon, &c. He regarded not the Sabbath, but prophan'd it at home; The publick wor≈øhip of God, and Preaching of the Word, he ≈øeldome or never attended; delighted much in the company of drunken Mini≈øters. This man, having much wa≈øted his e≈øtate by his riotous cour≈øes, was of late pur≈øued with arre≈øts and ≈øutes at Law for debts, which he had contracted; and divers that entred into bond for him left to ruine, and impri≈øonment; Ma≈øter Sprackling had Executions out again≈øt him, and Bailiffs ready to apprehend him, whereby he was con≈øtreined to make his own hou≈øe his pri≈øon, to keep home, and could not dominier abroad, and ride about as heretofore. Upon this occa≈øion he grew ≈øad, cholerick, and petulent, and full of rage in his hou≈øe; His Wife being divers times con≈øtreined to lock up her ≈øelf from him. She was a woman of precious report for many vertues, and (with Mary) did choo≈øe the better part: But upon Saturday at night December 11. la≈øt, Ma≈øter Sprackling being re≈øolved to mi≈øchief her, as the ≈øequel manife≈øted, He then being in the Kitchin of his hou≈øe, had one Lamming a neighbour of his with him, and he then ≈øent for one Knowler a Sea-man to come to him; but it being ten of the clock at night, he de≈øired to be excu≈øed, ≈øaying he was in bed; whereupon Ma≈øter Sprackling ≈øent for one Martin, a poor old man, a Tenant, and neighbour of his, who (though in bed) did ari≈øe and
come to Ma≈øter Sprackling, and then Lamming de≈øired that he might go home, which reque≈øt Ma≈øter Sprackling granted. So there remained Ma≈øter Sprackling and his Wife, and Martin, and one Ewell, ≈øervant to Ma≈øter Sprackling, the≈øe four only in the Kitchin; His Daughter and Maid-≈øervant got away (≈øeeing his rage) and locked them≈øelves all night in an out-room far from the Kitchin. Mr. Sprackling would not go to bed, though it grew late, but commanded Martin to bind Ewells legs, which he did accordingly with a dogs couplings, and ≈øo Ewell ≈øat bound all night after on the ground. Martin and Ewell conceived it only a frolick or ranting fit or humour come on him, ≈øuch as they had been formerly acquainted with.

Then he began to rage again≈øt his Wife, who ≈øate quietly there: her words to him were full of loving and ≈øweet expre≈ø≈øions; but he on a ≈øudden drew his Dagger, and ≈øtruck her with it on the face, which blow hurt her jaw; but ≈øhe was very patient, and ≈øayd little to him; but he ≈øtill raged again≈øt her; And towards morning the good Gentlewoman being weary, and in great fear, ro≈øe up to go out of the room, and lifting up her hand to open the dore, her Husband following her with a chopping-knife in his hand, cut her wri≈øt therewith, ≈øo, that the bone was cut in ≈øunder; her hand hung down only by the ≈øinewes and skin; No help was neer, Ewell bound, and Martin old and weak, and fearing his own life, dur≈øt not interpo≈øe, but only prayed his Mi≈øtris to ≈øtay and be quiet, he ≈øayd he hoped all would be well; And Martin got a napkin and bound up her hand with it. After this, towards morning, Mr. Sprackling, raging and rayling at her, da≈øhed her on the forehead with the Iron Cleaver or Chopping-knife. Then ≈øhe fell down bleeding, but recovered her ≈øelf on her knees, and kneeling cryed, and prayed to
God for pardon of her own ≈øins, and of her Husbands ≈øin, be≈øeeching God to forgive him, for ≈øhe forgave him. But, in the time of her praying thus, her Husband chopt her head in the mid≈øt into the brains, ≈øo that ≈øhe fell down ≈øtark dead in≈øtantly, lying in her own blood; Then he killed ≈øix dogs, four of which he threw be≈øides his wife, and after ≈øhe was dead, he cut her in the leg in two places, and compelled Martin to wa≈øh Ewells face with her blood, he al≈øo dipped linnen in her blood, and be≈ømeared Martin's face with her blood, and bebloudied his own face with it.

For this Fact Ma≈øter Sprackling was apprehended that night, having his Dagger in one hand, and Pi≈øtoll in the other hand; but he was ≈øurprized, and taken by one Martin Brook. The next day he was carried to Sandwich Jayl: And after the Maior of Sandwich (being Coroner) and his Inque≈øt had ≈øate upon the death of this Gentlewoman, Martin al≈øo was ≈øent to Pri≈øon. The Se≈ø≈øions at Sandwich followed on Friday the 22. of April la≈øt. The Steward of the Court Mr. Peter Peak a Coun≈øellour of Grayes-Inne, gave a godly and learned charge to the Grand Inque≈øt, and, after mention of many ≈øins, he ≈øpake of the crying ≈øin of Murther, what a land-defiling and God-provoking ≈øin it was, as he evidenced by many examples; As, of the Sword not departing from the hou≈øe of David, for his murther of Uriah, by the Sword of the Ammonites; For the blood of Naboth, the dogs lickd the bloud of Ahab, and three≈øcore and ten ≈øons of his had their bloud ≈øhed afterward, and dogs did eat bloudy Jezabel; The ≈øons of bloudy Saul hang'd up, &c. And, for the direction of the Court, he came to ≈øome ca≈øes of Murther, ≈øhewing in ≈øuch ca≈øes there was malice expre≈øt, malice implyed, malice ≈øupplyed. Malice expre≈øt, and Murther thereupon, is ordinary: but if a man intend maliciou≈øly
to kill one, and it fall out, that he kill not the party, which he de≈øired to mi≈øchief, but another, it is murther. He ≈øhewed out of his Law-books, that a Father-in-law procured phy≈øick for his ≈øick Son-in-law; The Phy≈øician pre≈øcribed a comfortable Medicine, which the Apothecary made accordingly of ≈øeverall Ingredients; The Son-in law took ≈øome of it, but it had almo≈øt killed him, though cordiall Phy≈øick; The Father-in-law went to the Doctor of Phy≈øick, and told him how the Cordiall wrought; Hereupon the Apothecary was ≈øent for, and examined touching the Ingredients; He replied, he had put nothing in, but as the Phy≈øician directed, and that he knew the phy≈øick ≈øo Cordiall, that he would take it him≈øelf, and, to ju≈øtifie him≈øelf, did take part of that Medicine; but, he ≈øoon dyed: Afterwards it was found out, that the wife of the ≈øick man had put poy≈øon in the Medicine, thinking thereby to poy≈øon her Husband; but, he being of a ≈øtronger nature than the Apothecary, did e≈øcape, though hardly: but the woman was executed for the Apothecaries death, though ≈øhe intended not his death, becau≈øe there was malice expre≈øt, murther intended.

Malice implyed was where no expre≈ø≈øion of malice in words, &c. appeared in the ≈ølayer; as if a Son put his aged Father out of dores in a fro≈øty night, and he dy, its murther; Non refert an occidat, an cau≈øam mortis praebeat. If two be together, and, no provocation given or known, one kill the other, there is malice implied; it's Murther.

Malice ≈øupplied, this he ≈øhewed in two Children in King Henry the ≈øeventh's time, one nine year old, the other eleven; one kill'd the other, and, becau≈øe the ≈ølayer denyed the fact, and cunningly by excu≈øes ≈øought to hide it, and to acquit him≈øelf of it, it was found Murther; Malice was ≈øupplyed in Law, to be in the Child though not of competent age, and the Child was thereupon executed.

After the Grand Inque≈øt had received the Bill of Indictment, which was pre≈øented in Court by Mr. Steward Leukner, brother of Mr. Spracklings wife, the Inque≈øt going together, returned to the Bar, finding both Mr. Sprackling, and Martin guilty of the Murther of Mi≈øtris Sprackling. After dinner the Jury of life and death was called, Mr. Sprackling and Martin pleaded not guilty; and referred them≈øelves to a fair tryall: Mr. Sprackling held up his trembling hand at the Bar; but when the Jury came one by one to be ≈øworn, he excepred again≈øt, and put by 20. of them, ≈øhewing no rea≈øon for it; but, he not being permitted by Law to except again≈øt any more, without ≈øhewing rea≈øon for it, a Jury was at la≈øt filled up and ≈øworn. And the murther as before rehear≈øed, was proved by Ewell; (for Martin being a Pri≈øoner and party, could give no evidence.)

Mr. Sprackling pleaded for him≈øelf, that he was mad when he kill'd his Wife; and that he knew not what he did: but Lamming, being depo≈øed, te≈øtified, that when he left Mr. Sprackling, that Saturday night, he perceived no di≈øtemper in him, but that he was as he u≈øed to be at other times: And Jo≈øeph Cowell his Tenant, who ≈øaw him that Sabbath after the Murther done, te≈øtified that he was as he u≈øed to be, only he ≈øpake thick, and often of bloud, blood, blood. And it was te≈øtified by Roger Streven, who ≈øaw him next morning after the fact, when he went to Pri≈øon; He depo≈øed that he ≈øaw no ≈øign of di≈øtraction in him, but was rationall in his di≈øcour≈øe, and provided a Wagon with a bed in it for his conveyance to Sandwich Pri≈øon; And Roger Streven depo≈øed, that he heard it affirmed that Mr. Sprackling ≈øaid after his wife was dead, now let us kill the Dogs, and then they'l ≈øay we are mad indeed.

And ≈øince the Tryall, it is known that Mr. Sprackling
writ a Letter that Saturday morning to Roger Hooper, a Sea-man, to buy him Goods at London, and ≈øuch, and ≈øuch Books; and, to pay money at London for him; which Letter was rationall, in his u≈øuall form of writing. And ≈øince the tryall al≈øo, Mr. Hope≈øtill Tilden of Sandwich affirmed in the hearing of many, that he being divers times with Mr. Sprackling in Pri≈øon, heard him ≈øay, he kill'd his Wife, becau≈øe ≈øhe was a traitour to him, and ≈øayd, that if it were your ca≈øe Hope≈øtill, you would do the like to ≈øuch a Wife that went about to betray you, and undo you, and deliver you to the Bailiffs. And, I ≈øince hear, he affirmed the ≈øame to another, that morning he went to Pri≈øon, ≈øaying, ≈øhe left the dores open on purpo≈øe, &c. And for further Evidence at the tryall, many witne≈ø≈øes were called and ≈øworn, that te≈øtified, that this bloudy Oxe did u≈øe to pu≈øh in former time; and, that it was not a fit of frenzy at that time of the Murther rehear≈øed; but, that he was of an habitual bloody di≈øpo≈øition and practi≈øe. One John Ru≈ø≈øell depo≈øed, that about twenty year before, he ≈øaw Mr. Sprackling endeavour to run one John Simons through with his naked Rapier, in St. Peters Pari≈øh, at a Tap-hou≈øe there, and had nayled him to the wall, had not he took hold on the hilt of the Rapier; and, that in another Tap-hou≈øe there, he ≈øaw Mr. Sprackling quarrell with one Giles, and drew his Sword at him; but, the Deponent did not follow Ma≈øter Sprackling into the next Room where Giles was; but, he ≈øaw Giles come bleeding out.

One Robert Li≈øter depo≈øed, that Mr. Sprackling being wor≈øted in a quarrell in a Tap-hou≈øe in that Pari≈øh, lay there at one Homans all night, and ≈øent for his man Cor≈ølet, his Champion, and next day morning, in cold blood, commanded his man Cor≈ølet to fall on the ≈øaid Robert Li≈øter, which he did pre≈øently, and ≈øtrook the ≈øaid Li≈øter on
the jaw with a cudgell, whereby a tumult aro≈øe; but, company parted them: And one Goble, a Shoemaker, was run into the bowells, in that Pari≈øh, another time, when Mr. Sprackling was in the affray.

Edward Taddy depo≈øed, that he being Con≈øtable, did a≈ø≈øi≈øt Humphery Pudner, the Maior of Dovers Deputy, at St. Johns pari≈øh, and Richard Langley, Deputy to the Maior of Sandwich, at St. Laurence Pari≈øh, when they three had an Order to di≈øarm Mr. Sprackling, and, having taken and ≈øecured the Arms in his hou≈øe, Mr. Sprackling a≈ø≈øaulted the ≈øaid Edward Taddy, when he met him ≈øome moneths after; And Humphrey Pudner depo≈øed, that he drew upon him al≈øo in the ≈øtreet; and, that he being Officer, di≈øarm'd Mr. Sprackling in an affray, which he made in a Taphou≈øe in St. Johns Pari≈øh; And William Grant depo≈øed, that in that Pari≈øh he drew at him, and had cleav'd his head with his Cutla≈øh, if he had not put by the blow. Others were ready to depo≈øe many ≈øuch bloody a≈ø≈øaults done by Mr. Sprackling: But (above all) the death of Richard Langley of St. Laurence Pari≈øh, was mentioned in Court. This Richard Langley was a very godly man, zealous for God and the State, had ≈øeized on Mr. Spracklings Arms, and Articled again≈øt him, ≈øo that Mr. Sprackling was ≈øecured at Canterbury, at the fir≈øt of the Parliament: But Mr. Sprackling (being at liberty in the year 1648.) the day before the Kenti≈øh In≈øurrection bur≈øt out, armed hor≈øe and men, and went down from his own hou≈øe to the Sea-town there, called Ram≈øgate; that is Romans-gate, where the Romans fir≈øt Landed when they ≈øubdued this Nation: And Richard Langley living there, was ≈øought for; but, he hid him≈øelf in his hou≈øe for a time; but, hearing that Mr. Sprackling was there at the Tavern with Hor≈øe and Arms, and a rude crew with him, Langley crept out of his own hou≈øe, and
≈øtole away, and got to one Mi≈øtris John≈øons hou≈øe, and making his ≈øad ca≈øe known, how Mr. Sprackling ≈øought his blood, The good Gentlewoman lent him her Mare, and Langley pre≈øently fled out: but, Mr. Sprackling, hearing that Langley was got away, his two men, Allen and Emer≈øom, went after him; One Ma≈øter John John≈øon depo≈øed, that he ≈øaw them ride af ‚Ä¢ er Langley, ≈øo ≈øoon as Langley was got on hor≈øe-back, and that Mr. Sprackling's hor≈øe pur≈øued, and they had their Pi≈øtolls pre≈øented, as they rid by Mi≈øtris John≈øons Gate after Langley, whom they overtook about two miles off, and there he was ≈øhot through his body with a brace of bullets, which entred his back, and came forth at his brea≈øt, and ≈øo he was left wallowing in his blood, and died pre≈øently, leaving behind him a Widow and thirteen Orphans in a ≈øad condition. Whereupon Paul Allen fled, and is not yet taken: But Emer≈øom, though he were afterwards a Souldier in that In≈øurrection, Yet he was apprehended and Executed at Canterbury. It was not proved that Mr. Sprackling commanded them to kill Langley; But it's certain, that Mr. Sprakling was Commander in chief there that day, and acted as Commi≈ø≈øioner, and ≈øent for divers hone≈øt men, and impri≈øoned ≈øome in his hou≈øe, and afterwards went to Sea, and continued with the R ‚Ä¢ volted Ships. And it was depo≈øed at Ma≈øter Sprackling's tryall, that he had often threatned Richard Langley, and that before Richard Langley was m ‚Ä¢ rthered, M. Sprackling ≈øeeing him in the ≈øtreet, drew his Sword at him, and flouri≈øhed it over his own head, and was ready to a≈ø≈øault Richard Langley, but was prevented by others. And it was depo≈øed al≈øo that before the Murther of Richard Langley, Mr. Sprackling went out of the Tavern and pur≈øued Langley to his own hou≈øe with naked weapon in his hand, and there call'd for him, and ≈øought
him, but not finding him departed, and going out, let fall his Pi≈øtoll in the entry of Langley's hou≈øe, which Pi≈øtoll the Witne≈ø≈øe ≈øaw there, and took it up.

After the Court had heard the Evidence again≈øt Ma≈øter Sprackling, leave was given him to ≈øpeak for him≈øelf, and to bring what witne≈øs he plea≈øed in his defence, he and they ≈øhould be fairly heard. He named two Lawyers for his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance in form of Law, but none appeared. Two Phy≈øicians appeared in Court for him, and ≈øome women, to prove he was mad: but they ≈øpake only generall things; only one Phy≈øician depo≈øed, that he had let him blood four times together in a fever, about a year before, and that then he was in a di≈øtracted fitt; but none could ≈øwear he was di≈øtracted, neer, at, or after the Murther committed; only that he u≈øed to be outragious in pa≈ø≈øion, &c.
The Jury, giving up their Verdict, ≈øaid, they found Mr. Sprackling guilty of wilfull Murther.

But they acquitted Martin, having no proof that he had Combined to kill the Gentlewoman, or a≈ø≈øi≈øted in killing her; but that, meerly out of fear of death to him≈øelf, he was willing to humour his Ma≈øter in binding Ewell, and in praying Mrs. Sprackling to ≈øtay: and Ewell upon oath ≈øayd, that he could not ≈øwear that he ≈øaw Martin lay hands on her, to keep her from going out, and Martin having al≈øo a good te≈øtimoniall of all his neighbours, of his peaceable and harmle≈øs life. The ≈øentence of death being pronounced by the Maior of Sandwich again≈øt Ma≈øter Sprackling; Ma≈øter Peak, the Steward, made a patheticall exhortation to Mr. Sprackling to repent; he ≈øhewed him the heinou≈øne≈øs of the fact, and aggravated it in regard of the murthered Gentlewomans worth, in the admirable graces and vertues that ≈øhined forth in her, &c. But Mr. Sprackling an≈øwered; No man can judge between
